content: The House and Senate approved FY1999 defense bills, with additional funding of $8.3 billion, signed into law on October 17 and 20. The FY1999 defense bill, signed into law on October 21, provides $8.3 billion in additional funding for various defense-related purposes, including Bosnia operations, military readiness, intelligence, missile defense, year 2000 fixes, storm damage repairs, purchasing fissile materials from Russia, antiterrorism activities, and defense counter-drug activities. The FY1999 defense bill provides funding for military activities of the Department of Defense, including pay, benefits, weapons procurement, and research. It also includes small amounts for the Central Intelligence Agency retirement fund and intelligence community management. Additionally, classified amounts are allocated for national foreign intelligence activities. The FY1999 defense bill allocates funds for military activities of the Department of Defense, including pay, benefits, weapons procurement, and research. It also includes funding for the Central Intelligence Agency retirement fund and intelligence community management. The Administration's budget included $270.6 billion for national defense, with $250.8 billion requested in the defense appropriations bill. Congress also passes a national defense authorization bill annually, which details defense programs similar to the appropriations bill. Congressional debate over major defense policy and funding issues usually occurs mainly in action on the authorization bill. This report tracks congressional action on both defense authorization and appropriations bills. Congress completed action on the annual defense authorization and appropriations bills on October 1. The Senate approved S.Con.Res. 86 for the congressional budget resolution on April 2, while the House approved H.Con.Res. 284 on June 5. A conference agreement on the resolution was never completed. The House and Senate approved a conference agreement on H.R. 3579 for supplemental defense appropriations for FY1998, providing funding for military operations in Bosnia and Southwest Asia, domestic and defense disaster relief. The bill, signed into law as P.L. 105-174, allocates $2.7 billion for the Defense Department, including specific amounts for Bosnia, Southwest Asia, and disaster relief. The House and Senate approved an omnibus appropriations bill for FY1999 (H.R. 4328) providing $8.3 billion in defense-related funding, including allocations for Bosnia operations, military readiness, intelligence, missile defense, and year 2000 fixes in the Defense Department. The omnibus appropriations bill for FY1999 includes $1 billion for missile defense, $1.1 billion for year 2000 fixes in the Defense Department, $469 million for storm damage repairs, $200 million for the defense health program, $525 million to purchase fissile materials from Russia, $529 million for defense antiterrorism activities, and $42 million for defense counter-drug activities, all designated as emergency appropriations. Additionally, the bill includes rescissions of $67 million. The FY1999 omnibus appropriations bill includes emergency funds for missile defense, Y2K fixes, storm damage repairs, defense health program, purchasing fissile materials from Russia, antiterrorism, and counter-drug activities. The defense authorization and appropriations bills resolved issues related to China, including limitations on satellite and missile technology exports. The authorization conference dropped contentious China-related amendments, including a ban on satellite exports to China.
